# Small Water System Challenges

California has thousands of small water systems -- those serving 200 connections or fewer, or fewer than 1,000 people -- many of which face persistent technical, financial, and managerial challenges. These systems disproportionately serve rural and disadvantaged communities, making their compliance struggles an environmental justice concern addressed through programs like [SAFER Program - Consolidation](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/compliance/) and [DDW Mandatory Consolidation Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/).

## Definition of Small Systems
- Serving 200 connections or fewer
- Or serving fewer than 1,000 people
- Thousands of small systems in California

## Common Challenges

### Technical
- Limited technical expertise and part-time operators
- Aging infrastructure with deferred maintenance
- Increasing treatment complexity for emerging contaminants
- Monitoring requirements that strain limited staff

### Financial
- Small rate base limits revenue capacity
- Limited reserves for emergencies
- Capital improvement costs often exceed annual budgets
- Regulatory compliance costs continue to increase

### Managerial
- Part-time or volunteer operators and board members
- Limited administrative capacity for reporting
- Board/management turnover disrupts institutional knowledge
- Record keeping challenges affect compliance

## Common Violations
- Monitoring and reporting failures (most common)
- Treatment technique violations
- MCL exceedances (particularly nitrate and bacteria)
- Operator certification deficiencies

## Support Available

### Technical Assistance
Technical assistance providers funded by the state include RCAC, Community Water Center, and county environmental health departments. The [SWRCB Consolidation and Extension of Service](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/waterpartnership.html) program connects struggling systems with larger, viable utilities.

### Financial Assistance
- DWSRF (Drinking Water State Revolving Fund) with set-asides for small systems
- SAFER funding for failing and at-risk systems
- USDA Rural Development loans and grants
- State proposition funding dedicated to small system needs

## Take Action
1. Contact the [SAFER Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/compliance/) to assess eligibility for funding and technical assistance.
2. Review compliance requirements at [DDW Mandatory Consolidation Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/).
3. Explore consolidation options through [SWRCB Consolidation and Extension of Service](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/waterpartnership.html).
4. Contact your DDW district office for a compliance review and technical assistance referral.
5. Reach out to RCAC or Community Water Center for free technical support.

# Water System Consolidation Options

Consolidation -- combining water systems to improve service, compliance, and sustainability -- is a key strategy in California's approach to solving the small water system crisis. The [DDW Mandatory Consolidation Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/compliance/) gives the State Board authority to mandate consolidation for chronically failing systems.

## Types of Consolidation

### Physical Consolidation
Actual pipeline connections between systems where one system provides water to another. Requires infrastructure investment but delivers the most complete integration.

### Managerial Consolidation
Shared management and operations while systems remain physically separate. Contract services and shared operators reduce administrative burden and improve professional management.

### Full Merger
Systems become one legal entity with consolidated governance, operations, and finances. Provides the greatest economies of scale but requires the most complex organizational change.

## Benefits
- **Technical:** Shared expertise, better treatment, redundancy, economies of scale
- **Financial:** Larger rate base, improved funding eligibility, shared costs
- **Compliance:** Professional management, consistent operations, better monitoring

## Mandatory Consolidation (SB 88)
The State Board can mandate consolidation for failing systems after other options are exhausted, prioritizing public health protection. The [SAFER Program - Consolidation](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/) provides funding for mandated and voluntary consolidation projects.

## Voluntary Consolidation Incentives
Planning grants, construction funding through [SWRCB Consolidation and Extension of Service](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/waterpartnership.html), technical assistance, and rate stabilization are available to incentivize voluntary consolidation.

## Take Action
1. Review consolidation program options at [DDW Mandatory Consolidation Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/compliance/).
2. Explore funding for consolidation projects through the [SAFER Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/).
3. Learn about extension of service options at [SWRCB Consolidation and Extension of Service](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/waterpartnership.html).
4. Contact your DDW district office to discuss which consolidation model fits your situation.
5. Engage neighboring water systems early -- successful consolidation requires willing partners.

# Private Well Owner Responsibilities

Private domestic wells serving a single residence are generally not regulated by the state in California. This means well owners bear full responsibility for water quality testing, well maintenance, and any treatment needed to ensure safe drinking water. The [DDW Private Well Information](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/gama/well_owners.html) provides guidance, though enforcement falls to county environmental health departments.

## Owner Responsibilities

### Testing
Annual testing is recommended for coliform bacteria and nitrate, with broader mineral and contaminant analysis every 3-5 years. Testing should also occur after flooding, earthquakes, nearby contamination events, or any changes in taste, odor, or appearance. Use [GAMA Groundwater Information System](https://gamagroundwater.waterboards.ca.gov/gama/gamamap/public/) to check groundwater quality data in your area.

### Maintenance
- Protect the wellhead from contamination sources
- Maintain proper grading to prevent surface water pooling
- Monitor water level trends
- Inspect the well annually for structural integrity

### Treatment
If testing reveals contamination, the owner must install and maintain appropriate treatment -- point-of-use (under-sink) or point-of-entry (whole-house) systems. No state agency will provide treatment for private wells.

## Well Construction Standards
County permits are required for new wells, modifications, and destruction. Wells must meet DWR Bulletin 74 standards for construction, including setback requirements from septic systems and proper annular seals. The [EPA Private Drinking Water Wells](https://www.epa.gov/privatewells) provides additional guidance on well protection.

## Finding Certified Labs
Testing must be performed by ELAP-certified laboratories. Contact your county environmental health department or check the state lab directory for certified labs in your area.

## Take Action
1. Check groundwater conditions in your area at [DDW Private Well Information](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/gama/well_owners.html).
2. Review well protection guidance at [EPA Private Drinking Water Wells](https://www.epa.gov/privatewells).
3. Search local groundwater quality data using the [GAMA Groundwater Information System](https://gamagroundwater.waterboards.ca.gov/gama/gamamap/public/).
4. Test your well annually for bacteria and nitrate -- contact your county environmental health department for certified labs.
5. If you're buying property with a well, request recent water quality testing results before closing.

# State Small Water System Permits

State Small Water Systems (SSWS) serve 5-14 connections and fall below the federal threshold for Public Water System regulation. In California, these systems are regulated by local primacy agencies -- typically county environmental health departments -- under state-specific requirements established by the [DDW Small Water System Compliance](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/publicwatersystems.html) program.

## Regulatory Framework

State Small Water Systems are not classified as Public Water Systems under federal law, but California imposes its own requirements including permits, water quality monitoring, and minimum facility standards. The [DDW Compliance and Enforcement](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/compliance/) program provides oversight when local agencies identify violations.

## Operating Requirements

### Water Quality
Systems must meet primary drinking water standards, with testing frequency determined by the local agency. Results must be reported to the county, and violations trigger corrective action requirements.

### Physical Standards
Source protection, treatment (if needed), adequate storage capacity, and distribution system standards must all meet county requirements. The [EPA Small Drinking Water Systems Compliance](https://www.epa.gov/dwreginfo) provides supplementary federal guidance.

## Permitting Process
1. Apply to county environmental health department
2. Submit to engineering review of system design
3. Obtain construction permit and complete installation
4. Pass final inspection
5. Receive operating permit with ongoing conditions

## Common Issues and Solutions
Failed water quality testing, operating without a permit, and inadequate facilities are the most common violations. Solutions include treatment installation, source improvement, or consolidation with a nearby Public Water System.

## Take Action
1. Review small system requirements at [DDW Small Water System Compliance](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/publicwatersystems.html).
2. Check compliance and enforcement standards at [DDW Compliance and Enforcement](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/compliance/).
3. Access federal guidance at [EPA Small Drinking Water Systems Compliance](https://www.epa.gov/dwreginfo).
4. Contact your county environmental health department for permit applications and inspection schedules.
5. If your system has compliance issues, ask about technical assistance programs before violations escalate.

# Transient Non-Community Water Systems

Transient Non-Community Water Systems (TNCWSs) serve at least 25 different people daily for at least 60 days per year -- think restaurants, gas stations, campgrounds, rest stops, and churches with meal service. Because users change daily, monitoring focuses on acute health risks rather than chronic exposure. The [DDW Small Water System Compliance](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/publicwatersystems.html) program oversees these systems.

## Regulatory Requirements

### Permit
All TNCWSs must hold an operating permit from DDW or the local primacy agency. Operating without a permit is a violation that can result in enforcement action through [DDW Compliance and Enforcement](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/compliance/).

### Monitoring
- Coliform bacteria testing: quarterly minimum
- Nitrate: annually
- Reduced monitoring compared to community systems, reflecting transient exposure patterns

### Reporting
Systems must submit monitoring results to their regulatory agency, notify of violations promptly, and complete annual reporting requirements.

## Differences from Community Systems
TNCWSs have reduced monitoring requirements and fewer contaminants monitored because different users don't accumulate chronic exposure. Regulatory focus emphasizes acute (immediate) health protection. The [EPA Small Drinking Water Systems Compliance](https://www.epa.gov/dwreginfo) explains the federal classification framework.

## Common Violations
- Monitoring and reporting failures (most common)
- Coliform bacteria detections
- Operating without a valid permit

## Take Action
1. Verify your system classification at [DDW Small Water System Compliance](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/publicwatersystems.html).
2. Review compliance requirements at [DDW Compliance and Enforcement](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/compliance/).
3. Access federal classification guidance at [EPA Small Drinking Water Systems Compliance](https://www.epa.gov/dwreginfo).
4. Contact your local primacy agency (DDW district office or county) for monitoring schedule requirements.
5. Maintain current operator training and ensure backup operators are available.

# Non-Transient Non-Community Water Systems

Non-Transient Non-Community Water Systems (NTNCWSs) serve at least 25 of the same people for at least 6 months per year -- schools, factories, office buildings, hospitals, and prisons. Because the same people are regularly exposed, monitoring requirements are more comprehensive than for transient systems, addressing both acute and chronic health risks. The [DDW Small Water System Compliance](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/publicwatersystems.html) provides regulatory guidance.

## More Stringent Requirements
NTNCWSs must meet monitoring requirements similar to community systems because regular users accumulate chronic exposure. This includes monthly-to-quarterly coliform testing, annual nitrate monitoring, and testing for many additional contaminants on prescribed schedules.

## Schools Specifically
AB 746 requires lead testing at school drinking water outlets with an action level of 15 ppb. Schools exceeding the action level must remediate and report results publicly. These requirements apply regardless of whether the school is on a community water system or its own NTNCWS. [DDW Compliance and Enforcement](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/compliance/) tracks school testing compliance.

## Common Challenges
- Aging infrastructure in older school buildings
- Limited dedicated funding for water system maintenance
- Part-time operation with varying usage patterns
- Multiple buildings creating complex distribution systems

## Resources
The [EPA Small Drinking Water Systems Compliance](https://www.epa.gov/dwreginfo) provides guidance on federal requirements, monitoring schedules, and available technical assistance for NTNCWSs.

## Take Action
1. Review NTNCWS requirements at [DDW Small Water System Compliance](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/publicwatersystems.html).
2. Check compliance status and enforcement at [DDW Compliance and Enforcement](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/compliance/).
3. Access federal guidance at [EPA Small Drinking Water Systems Compliance](https://www.epa.gov/dwreginfo).
4. For schools: ensure lead testing under AB 746 is current and results are publicly posted.
5. Contact your DDW district office for technical assistance and to discuss monitoring schedules.

# Rural Water System Funding Programs

Multiple state and federal funding programs target rural and small community water systems in California. The [SAFER Program Funding](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/) is the state's primary vehicle for addressing failing and at-risk water systems, while [SWRCB Grants and Loans Overview](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/grants_loans/) provides a comprehensive directory of available funding.

## USDA Rural Development
The Water and Waste Disposal program serves rural areas (population under 10,000) with loans at reduced interest rates and grants for the lowest-income communities. Circuit rider programs provide hands-on technical assistance and grant writing support.

## State Revolving Funds
The [Drinking Water State Revolving Fund](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/services/funding/) includes set-asides for small systems, with technical assistance funding, capacity development support, and disadvantaged community grants offering reduced interest rates and principal forgiveness.

## SAFER Program
The SAFER (Safe and Affordable Funding for Equity and Resilience) program focuses specifically on small and disadvantaged systems with administrator authority for consolidation projects, emergency solutions, and long-term infrastructure investments.

## Proposition Funding
Bond measures (Prop 1, 2014 and Prop 68, 2018) include dedicated small system funding for infrastructure improvements.

## Application Tips
1. Identify your specific need (treatment, infrastructure, consolidation)
2. Contact a technical assistance provider for help with applications
3. Complete required planning documents
4. Apply to the appropriate program through FAAST
5. Combine funding sources when a single program won't cover total costs

The [EPA DWSRF Program](https://www.epa.gov/dwsrf) provides additional federal funding context.

## Take Action
1. Explore funding options at [SAFER Program Funding](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/).
2. Browse all available grants and loans at [SWRCB Grants and Loans Overview](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/grants_loans/).
3. Apply for DWSRF funding at [Drinking Water State Revolving Fund](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/services/funding/).
4. Review federal DWSRF guidance at [EPA DWSRF Program](https://www.epa.gov/dwsrf).
5. Contact RCAC or another technical assistance provider for free help with funding applications.

# Technical Assistance for Small Systems

California funds multiple technical assistance (TA) providers to help small water systems achieve and maintain compliance. These providers offer free or low-cost services including on-site troubleshooting, compliance support, operator training, and board governance guidance. The [DDW Small Water Systems Technical Assistance](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/publicwatersystems.html) program coordinates state-funded TA.

## State-Funded TA Providers

### Rural Community Assistance Corporation (RCAC)
[RCAC Technical Assistance](https://www.rcac.org/events/drinking-water-compliance/) provides comprehensive support including technical assistance, financial planning, environmental review, and training for small water systems throughout California.

### Community Water Center
Advocacy-focused TA provider offering community organizing, technical support, policy development, and direct assistance to disadvantaged communities.

## Circuit Rider Programs
Circuit riders are traveling technical experts who visit small systems regularly, providing on-site operations assistance, compliance help, emergency response support, and board training. This hands-on model is particularly effective for isolated rural systems.

## Training Programs
Operator training includes small water system certification courses, continuing education requirements, and hands-on training. Board training covers governance, financial management, rate setting, and compliance obligations.

## Emergency Assistance
When systems face emergencies (contamination events, equipment failure, natural disasters), TA providers can deploy quickly with interim solutions. The [EPA TMF Capacity Development](https://www.epa.gov/dwcapacity) framework supports building long-term system capacity.

## Take Action
1. Find TA providers at [DDW Small Water Systems Technical Assistance](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/publicwatersystems.html).
2. Review capacity development resources at [EPA TMF Capacity Development](https://www.epa.gov/dwcapacity).
3. Contact [RCAC Technical Assistance](https://www.rcac.org/events/drinking-water-compliance/) for direct technical support.
4. Reach out to your DDW district office for a compliance assessment and TA referral.
5. In an emergency, contact DDW immediately -- interim solutions can be arranged quickly.

# Water System Rate Setting Basics

Setting appropriate water rates is critical for small system sustainability. Rates must cover full costs -- operations, maintenance, capital improvements, reserves, and debt service -- while complying with Proposition 218 requirements for property-related fees. Many small systems struggle with political resistance and affordability concerns that lead to chronic underfunding. The [SAFER Program Funding](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/) can assist systems that lack financial capacity.

## Revenue Requirements
Rates must cover all costs: daily operations and maintenance, planned capital improvements, emergency reserves, debt service on existing obligations, and regulatory compliance. Underfunding any category creates long-term system risk.

## Rate Setting Process
1. **Determine revenue needs** based on current and projected costs
2. **Design rate structure** balancing fixed charges, variable usage charges, and customer classes
3. **Complete Prop 218 process** with written notice, 45-day notice period, public hearing, and majority protest provision

## Prop 218 Requirements
Water rates are property-related fees subject to Proposition 218: charges cannot exceed cost of service, must be proportional to service provided, and cannot subsidize between customer classes. Written notice to all affected parcels is mandatory.

## Small System Challenges
Political resistance to rate increases, small rate base limiting revenue, difficulty recovering fixed costs, and affordability concerns are common barriers. TA providers offer rate study assistance through [SWRCB Grants and Loans Overview](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/grants_loans/), and [Drinking Water State Revolving Fund](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/services/funding/) can fund infrastructure to reduce long-term costs.

## Low-Income Assistance
The [EPA DWSRF Program](https://www.epa.gov/dwsrf) supports programs that help low-income customers afford water bills while ensuring systems achieve full cost recovery.

## Take Action
1. Explore funding support at [SAFER Program Funding](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/) if your system needs rate study assistance.
2. Browse financial resources at [SWRCB Grants and Loans Overview](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/grants_loans/).
3. Apply for infrastructure funding through [Drinking Water State Revolving Fund](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/services/funding/) to reduce long-term costs.
4. Review federal guidance at [EPA DWSRF Program](https://www.epa.gov/dwsrf).
5. Contact RCAC or another TA provider for free assistance with rate studies and Prop 218 compliance.

# Mutual Water Companies

A mutual water company is a private corporation where each water connection equals one share of stock -- stockholders are customers and vice versa. These non-profit entities are self-governing and exempt from CPUC rate regulation, but must meet the same drinking water quality standards as any other public water system under [DDW Mandatory Consolidation Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/compliance/) oversight.

## Regulation
Mutual water companies face dual regulation: water quality oversight from DDW or the local primacy agency (same standards as other public water systems), and corporate governance requirements under California Corporations Code including stockholder meetings, board elections, and annual reporting. Unlike investor-owned utilities, they are not regulated by the CPUC.

## Governance
Boards of directors are elected by stockholders and manage all company affairs including rate setting, infrastructure investment, and compliance. Stockholders have the right to vote for directors, approve major decisions, access company records, and attend meetings.

## Common Challenges
Many mutual water companies face challenges including volunteer management with limited professional expertise, difficulty funding capital improvements, increasing regulatory compliance burden, and aging infrastructure. The [SAFER Program - Consolidation](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/) provides funding for mutuals that need help.

## Converting or Consolidating
Options include selling to a larger investor-owned or public utility, merging with another mutual, converting to a public agency, or entering a managerial consolidation arrangement. The [SWRCB Consolidation and Extension of Service](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/waterpartnership.html) facilitates these transitions.

## Take Action
1. Review compliance requirements at [DDW Mandatory Consolidation Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/compliance/).
2. Explore funding and consolidation support through [SAFER Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/).
3. Learn about service extension options at [SWRCB Consolidation and Extension of Service](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/waterpartnership.html).
4. Contact your DDW district office to discuss compliance status and available assistance.
5. Attend your mutual's annual stockholder meeting and advocate for adequate rate-setting and infrastructure investment.
